data.title: Kozintsev, Grigori (film director)
data.meta_description: 'Kozintsev, Grigori (film director)' published in 'The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Global Shakespeare'
data.text:
Grigori Kozintsev was a Ukrainian, Russian, and Soviet theater and film director, particularly known in the West for his film adaptations of Hamlet and King Lear. This entry traces Kozintsev’s career in theater and film, which began soon after the October Revolution, when Kozintsev started training as an artist and stage designer in Kiev. After traveling to St. Petersburg (then known as Petrograd, and later Leningrad) in 1919, he became an active participant in the post-revolutionary avant-garde scene, eventually forming, with a group of friends, an experimental group known as FEKS (The Factory of the Eccentric Actor). Initially interested in stage performance, the group moved on to filmmaking by 1924, effectively launching Kozintsev’s career as a film director.
